Description: Little obvious impact as long as winds remain light, but after 3 very warm days grasses are now very dry and vulnerable.  Mountain snow and water supplies continue to be OK but we are dusty dry around our little horse farm

Tue unusual gently soaking rain on Friday really helped settle the dust and even soaked in a bit as ground had briefly thawed.  Still dry but this helps a bit. Mountain snowpack and water supplies still good as well as winter recreation
Light snow this week didn't appreciably change anything but has kept the surface a bit moist  Seasonally cool temperatures this past week, too.
No significant moisture/snow since 11/11/18 and before that 10/14/18.
Snowfall has been light.  2019 started very cold, but now temperatures are above normal.  Continued hand watering necessary.
8 inches of snow from 1/12 storm still melting when snow fell 1/18.  Ground and streets currently covered.
We are in a cycle of snow and thaw.  When ground is bare we are watering perennials.

I have dropped us back into the moderately dry category.  A quick look at my  precipitation records for the past ten Decembers shows that this December was the third driest since I began recording (2009). The three driest Decembers in my records have been 0.16" in 2011, 0.51" in 2009, and 0.54" in 2018.  The 0.54" for this past December is less than half of what we had on the three wettest years.  This past month we had quite a few days of precipitation, but nearly all of the storms left only a little bit of snow.

We lost some of the snowpack in this area due to warm temperatures this past week but gained about an inch of it back yesterday so I think we are not too far from where we were a week ago. Overall I think that this part of Grand County is pretty dry even though it looks snowy at the moment.
We got nearly 5.0" of snow (0.33" of precipitation) in the past 3 days.  I will put us at near normal for this week.  In the long term I think we are still mildly to moderately dry.

We've had good snowfall this week.  Wind has drifted some of the snow into snowbanks that will hold the moisture until spring unless we have an early warm-up.  I think that in the long term we are still below average precipitation but the last two weeks have definitely helped lessen the drought. For the present, the snowpack here is looking pretty good.
sunny and warmer than normal.
Little moisture yesterday did not change conditions.
No measurable precipitation this week.
Although we got some snow this past week, I believe we're closer to severely dry than mildly dry.

Wind 14mph WSW, yesterday into the night.  More expected today. Anxiety for fire potential building. It's a chore keeping tumbleweeds away from corrals and buildings. Sparrows and a pair of ravens follow behind to eat the weed seeds. Triticale fields have been scoured off by recent winds.

Enjoying the moisture.  What little we got will be gone with the promised winds Thurs-Sat.  Every time weeds are thrown out of the fences, multiple birds gather for the seeds and rodents. Not much forage for them otherwise. The dust is knocked out of the air temporarily - grateful for that.

Lots of wind yesterday and last night. Weeds tore down more fence and filled the yard. Blowing snow - guessing around 1 1/2" with just .03" moisture. Coyotes are a concern with entering people's yards and calling out dogs. Even though we had rain last week, the dirt got to blowing pretty good yesterday.

Getting moisture 1/100 at a time. Snowing this morning. Will have to address the tumbleweed situation before long.  Every fence and ditch is packed. Too breezy/windy to burn safely. Coyotes remain a concern as numbers appear to be high.Barn owl hanging around looking for food.
Dry and continued dryness, hardly any snow for December, makes several months in a row with little moisture.  I wouldn't be surprised to see a foothills fire break out with these conditions.
Small snow storms Have left only a few inches of accumulation which has melted/evaporated soon after the storms, leaving the ground nearly as dry as before.
Finally enough snow has fallen and not yet melted to leave the ground nearly covered by several inches. Where melted in thinner places, the ground is muddy a couple of inches deep.
Minimal snowfall before New Year's insufficient to take us back to normal.
Are we finally coming into a wetter pattern?
Back to the dust!
Though still dry, this week's snow cover very beneficial for hay and pasture.

Drought conditions persist! Western Arapahoe county is almost two inches below average for our water year.  Most cattle ranches are moving cattle to areas that received summer precipitation or are selling off their herds. Wheat stands are in very poor condition, after receiving very little precipitation this fall.

We bought this home about 5 years ago, and there was two to three feet of snow at this time of year. This year we only have 10 inches total, which is way better than the 2.5 inches we had at this time of year last year.
Some improvement has happened due to pulses of snow but not enough to kick us out of this category
To date, snowfall for this station is 74% of average and snow depth is 67% of average.  We'll need some significant storms to get back to normal.
Snowfall and snow depth are both 71% for the season. This site seems to be getting screwed with snowfall since most areas around here are 85-105%. Hopefully conditions improve soon.
The last two storms dropped 1.09" of water equivalent, which helps our drought situation. At this site, snowpack and snowfall for the season are at 88% and 85% of average, respectively.
Snowfall for the season is 88% of average, snow depth is 91% of average.

We received 0.04" of precipitation in the form of 0.4" of snow over the past week.  Much below average temperatures and light winds to start the week, then above average temperatures and stronger winds late week.  Virtually no snow cover.  Ground conditions remain dry.  Only 0.64" of precipitation between 1 Nov 2018 and 7 Jan 2019, which is unusually low.

Finally some welcomed moisture.  We received 0.39" of precipitation (all rain, just a trace of snow) from a storm on 11-12 Jan.  This precipitation, combined with near-average temperatures and light winds, have improved ground conditions to mildly dry.

We received 0.05" of precipitation (one round of a rain-snow mix) over the past week.  Temperatures were a few degrees above average, but winds were light resulting in mildly dry ground conditions.  Month-to-date precipitation now at 0.48", which already eclipses the total monthly average (0.40").

Another 0.31" of precipitation in the form of 3.8" of snow this week.  It's been windy this week, but temperatures have been near to slightly below average and the 6 days of snow cover have helped limit surface evaporation.  Month-to-date precipitation is now 0.79" (210% of normal) with a snowfall totaling 4.2", making a dent in the seasonal drought conditions.

We have had some really good snow storms and the colder temperatures are keeping it on the ground. The outlying areas where more agriculture takes place seem to have less so there may not be as much ground moisture accumulating. Run-off in the spring should allow for plenty of irrigation water for gardening and farming. We welcome more snow!
1.54" of moisture and 30.5" of snow was a huge help over the last 5 days.
16.1" of snow and 1.11" of moisture since New Years.  We need this to continue.
Storm after storm is helping.
No snow this week.

This area of Ponderosa pine forest is near normal for moisture with snow remaining on the ground since January 1.  Precipitation for the past 8 days measures 1.25" with 6.0"Total Snow remaining at report time.  Deer, rabbits, wild turkeys find bare vegetation on South facing lawns and slopes.  The past 3 months show normal recordings of precipitation for this time of year after a dry Fall.

With 2 snowstorms in the past 7 days, the driving in to town has been difficult at times.  Total snow measured in 7 days is 11" with 9" snowpack remaining in the open areas in our ponderosa pine forest area.  Snowpack began on Jan 11 so this bodes well for water supply later this year. Deer, rabbits, wild turkeys forage on exposed hillsides and lawns and find plenty of water in neighbor's ponds that are kept running and open.
Totally missed last week's storm that got Denver -- not a flake here but plenty of wind.  Grassy vegetation very crisp and dry now,especially after 3 days with temps near 60F this week.

Water supplies and mountain snowpack continue in good shape but we're still dry here from below average precip since last summer. A little snow on Weds and subsequent cold weather means we're not getting worse here.

Not many impacts, and water supplies good with building snowpack in our high mountains-- but local precip very limited.  We had some local blowing dust when wind gusts exceeded 30 mph this past week. No fire issues yet with cold weather, but that could change quickly if March brings no wet snows
Snow cover retains moisture.  Exposed areas dry.
Snow is still covering shady places, exposed ground is dry.  A few bulbs just poling through.

January ends with 1.05" of snow and 0.41" of precipitation. It is very dry. Also it has been cold in the mornings, sometimes in the single digits. The lack of precipitation, cold air, and winds combine to stress the vegetation. The birds continue to flock to my heated bird bath. When I can I water trees and raised beds that are planted with garlic. Exposed soil is cracked.

January precipitation totals were near normal., so will go with near normal on the scale bar.  As far as this winter season is concerned however, I think we are still dry.  As I look at the snow I have piled up from the few times I've plowed this winter I'd estimate that I have about 60% as much depth in snow piles as I've had on average winters.  That's not a very scientific measurement to be sure but I think it is an indication that we are still below normal precipitation in the long term at this station.

I will keep us at the near normal category for the short term.  We had about 3.0" of snow in the past week with a lot of wind which made for solid drifts of hard packed, dense snow in protected areas.  We also have bare ridge tops as a result of the wind.  I still feel that at this elevation, in this area, we are below average snowpack in the long term. According to the local newspaper, the soil conservation district end of January snow measurement was above 100% of the 30 year average, so snow up high where they take those measurements is very good at present.  Here in the Colorado River Valley however, I think we are still on the low side of normal for this winter season, but we are in far better shape than we were on this date a year ago.  Total snow on the ground at this station on 2/9/18 was 0.5".  Today, 2/9/19, I am reporting 8.0" total snow on the ground.
We had 3.2" of snow this past week which is not all that impressive, but it was wet snow for this time of year with a water equivalent of 0.32".  I will keep us at near normal again this week.

We have had 0.07" of precipitation at this station this week.  One of the winter indicators that seems fairly reliable in this area regarding snowpack depth is watching the mule deer and elk patterns.  We are in a natural winter feeding ground area.  On an average or above average snowfall year the animals will all be at a lower elevation than our property by this time of year.  On a dry year like last year they will remain at higher elevations than our property.  This year the majority of the animals have moved down below us, however, most days we will see anywhere from 8 to 30 deer on our property, which is a pretty good indicator that we are probably on the low side of average snowpack depth for late February, but are not all that low.
All traces of snow are gone. Some ice north of the privacy fence.
Has been cold enough for the snow to stay on the ground.
Finally some moisture but little snow remaining on the ground.
some moisture and cool temps have helped a bit with dry conditions.

Wind.  Every day is wind. Yard full of weeds, but isn't safe to burn and pointless to pitch over the fence. Air is full of dust off feedlots and dirt roads. Big birds: hawk, owl, pair of ravens and crows hanging close to buildings and corrals.
Continued winds. Coyotes reported killing calves and injuring others. Neighbor digging post holes didn't find moisture till around 3'. Wednesday's snow produced no moisture.

Bad dirt storm on Saturday afternoon. Tumbleweeds continue to hinder corral work and tear down fences.  Ground is scoured in many places because of the wind. Snowed during the night but only has .04 moisture content.
Blizzard on Saturday. Melted to .19"  Ready for warmer temps. A little "green" coming up where moisture has collected.
Still calling it moderately dry, some golf courses limiting access due to dry conditions to prevent course damage.  Need precip in a hurry around here.
Some snow in the last two weeks, but still dry on the pasture, snow pack looks good however.  Seems colder than January
Ground has been covered with 0" to over 2' of snow in drifts, so moisture is being added to the ground as the snow melts, which is helping improve the drought conditions.

Snow depths from bare ground (30% around the house area) to snow covered with drifts of up to 2' (70% around the house). Open pastures have less deep snow but are covered, too. Warm temperatures make for muddy ground already.
Only 0.21 of an inch of precipitation over the last two full months.
Present snow cover is great but we need more precipitation.
Over the last four months we have received only 0.61 inches of precipitation.
Even as the snow melts the soil remains dry.
84% of average snowpack, and 80% average snowfall for the water year at this station.
Snowfall for the date is 79% of average, snow depth is 90% of average. The weather forecast is promising, so hopefully we'll be above average by next week.

For the date, snowfall is 104" (100% of average), and snow depth is 39" (143% of average). This is the first time since I began Condition Monitoring Reports (10-2017) that conditions have been in the Wet category. Hopefully this drought is almost over!
Snow depth is 115% of average, snowfall is 93% of average for this date.

No precipitation over the past week.  Temperature were much above normal (above 50F on 2 days, and above 60F on 2 other days), but winds were mostly light during all but the last day of the week.  For now ground conditions remain mildly dry.
Another 0.13" of precipitation in the form of 1.8" of snow.  Temperatures were below average and winds light, resulting in reduced surface evaporation and mildly dry ground conditions.

Just 0.02" of precipitation this week in the form of 0.7" of new snow.  The middle of the week was warm (56F), dry, and windy (peak gust 37 mph), but the week ended cool with some snow.  Water year 2018-19 (Oct 1 to present):  2.74" (normal 3.00", so we're 90% of normal).

We totaled 0.05" of precipitation, all in the form of 0.5" of snow, over the past week.  There was at least a trace of snow on 5 of the 7 days.  Below average temperatures with moderate winds have left ground conditions mildly dry.  Month-to-date precipitation is 0.20" (59% of average).

Some minor flooding occurred on Sunday Feb 3, 2019 when mid day rain fell and caused some melting of the snow. A couple of homes experienced flooding which came towards their houses and sandbags had to be used. This flooding was very isolated and was related to clogged drainage systems blocked by ice with water backing up. Some patches of ground on lawns remain dry when examined.

Snow has fallen but melts off quickly if warm. There have been some days of very cold temperature. Most people are glad to have some snow this year. The deer in town (about 250 head) seem to be doing alright with the winter. Most look well fed, not thin. They don't raid trash cans as much as some years.
Snow and ice are melting and creating mud in some places. Bird activity has increased with more birds around who can be quite noisy. some days are very windy.
Conditions are improving but need more moisture.
With this snow I am still down 8.00" of moisture the last 730 days.
It has been a dry week with no knew snow and hot. It affects are tourism because we are a ski valley and with no knew snow it can affect us

December was drier than normal but January certainly made up for it!  23" of snow fell measured to 2.28" precipitation which brings us to normal conditions.  Snow pack of 4" remains on the ground in this Ponderosa pine forest area of suburbia but at times amounted to 13" after several snowstorms.  Cold nights in the 20's have kept the snow around but with a week of 40 daytime temps, there are many bare spots.

This elevation of 6300 feet in Ponderosa pine forest (suburbia) remains at Normal for this time of year due to good snowfall in January of 23" measured and cold temps day and night that keep snowpack of at least 4" since January 11.  This week only had 2" of snow fall but the frigid below zero temps early in the week made school kids happy with a delayed start.

Near Normal conditions remain.  Snowpack was reduced to 2" in shaded areas a week ago, but with 3" of new snow the past few days along with night time temps in the teens, the snowpack has increased again to 4 or 5".  Deer are stretching as far up as they can reach to eat evergreens and trees are being stripped of bark.

The past 7 days have brought .75" precipitation so conditions remain normal.  The days were more warm so a good deal of snowpack had melted before this morning's report of 4" of snow.  Deer, rabbits, wild turkeys appear healthy and locating enough food.  And of note, birds have appeared this week:  house finches and other small birds.

We have close to two feet of snow in the pasture.  Compared to a completely dry pasture at this time last year, this is remarkable.  Ski areas near here are reporting they are at 114% above average.  I can attest that the skiing has been great in this area (Aspen to Snowmass) this year.  Skiing was absolutely awful in this area last year.

Huge increase in snowpack from last year (reported by the Roaring Fork Conservancy today):

Snowpack in the Roaring Fork Watershed:
February 14, 2019: 119% of normal.  
February 14, 2018: 77% of normal.  

www.roaringfork.org

The ground seems fairly saturated! Just got 0.14 inch of rain yesterday and last night on top of 6 inches of melted snow and other rain/snow earlier this winter. MUCH better than last winter and/or all of last year. So much moisture now is affecting my ability to access parts of the property, including being able to drive roads in order to get hay to my horses. Haven't been able to get a regular hay delivery (with semis) because the driveway is so muddy; haven't been able to get the water man to my house cistern for the same reason. Minor inconveniences, considering! On the plus side, the horses are reaping the benefits of water again. Regarding recreation/tourism, I've had to postpone people who want to come see the mustangs (not generally a good time of year anyway (in a normal year)).

Disappointment Creek is flowing well (very muddy). Even Spring Creek is flowing with snowmelt (and seeps coming to the surface?), something I've never seen in at least 12 years of close monitoring of Spring Creek Basin. There's no snow in lower Disappointment Valley, but there are still damp patches of ground in some places. Some grass is coming up in my yard; the deer are happy. The growing is limited, though, and I don't see it in other areas yet. Hopeful! That said, there are a LOT of orange juniper and pinon trees around.

Several recent wet snows along with cooler than average March temperatures have helped replenish near-surface soil moisture.  Nearby mountain snowpack also remains in great shape. Grasses are starting to green up and tree buds are swelling

Very wet winter/early spring, along with cold temperatures, are delaying emergence of forbs, and blooming of fruit trees. Our water collection tanks were full by the end of January, which is very unusual.
Soil is not cracked.  Spring bulbs are appearing. Snow is lingering in shady areas.
As the day time temperature rises, water is running off lawns with melting of snow.
Bulbs are pushing up through leaf matter. Snow piles are nearly gone. Leaf buds re swelling. Ground is not cracked.
Soil moist for spring clean up. Lilac bushes are showing green. Crocus and snowdrops almost over with daffodils taking charge.

Thus far in March I measured more precipitation than the past few months combined. We received some very wet snowfall and rain. Temperatures are beginning to warm up, although below freezing temperatures occur overnight. Many species of birds have returned and fruit trees are beginning to bud.

February ended with dry, warm weather.  Much of our snowpack disappeared in just a few days.  I compared this February's stats with the past 10 years and found that this year's February snowfall (7.5") was only 59% of the 10 year average however, the precipitation for this past month was (0.69") which is 80% of the ten year average.  This February, 2019, was the driest February I've recorded in the ten years I've been measuring in terms of new snowfall, but was the 3rd driest in terms of actual precipitation. Overall, we ended the month below average so will put us at mildly dry.

Moderately wet is a category we rarely get to choose in this area but I will go with that for this week because we received 0.99" of precipitation.  0.28" came from rain, the rest came from wet snow which has drifted and packed in so that it probably will not melt too rapidly.  Things are looking good as of this week.
We received a little over a half inch of precipitation this week so we are still above average so far for the month of March.

We only received 0.05" of precipitation this past week.  Wind prone ridges are now snow free but there is plenty of drifted snow in protected areas.  So far the melting process has been slow, which is a good thing.  I do not think the snowpack is as much as we've had on some of our heavier winters, but there is enough that we should have a pretty decent run-off this spring.

There has been less run-off water than I would have expected this week given the warm temperatures and wind.  We are approaching 50% snow cover in this area ( not counting the 0.5" of snow this morning) and while we have water and mud to be sure, it isn't what I would have expected.  Some people I've talked to wonder if the ground has been so dry from the drought that the water is soaking into the soil more than usual rather than running off.  We had 0.07" of precipitation this past week, so we are probably on the boarder between near normal and mildly wet, but we've definitely dried out this week, so I'll put us at near normal.
A nice all-day light snowfall yesterday. Hoping for more.-
cool temps and just a little wind, so not a lot of drying this week.Snow is all melted on north side of privacy fence
A lot of moisture in the Wednesday 'blizzard' but I wouldn't call conditions moderately wet. The national drought monitor shows little change on the Colorado plains over the last 2 weeks.
Nice moisture this week.
Hope the moisture keeps coming.
Dug post hole 2' deep and very wet all the way.  Trees should be absorbing this water so will l be much more resistant to fire this summer.
This extreme cold is hard on the cattle.  Have lost several calves. Area hunters report high number of coyotes. Ready for Spring and rain.
Not much moisture in last week's snow. Winds every day, different directions.Bluebirds and robins showing up. Bracing for the promised high wind on Wednesday.

Last week's storm gave us .12" rain but the hurricane winds took it and more out immediately.  Many trees down, buildings and vehicles with severe damage, fences tore down. Tumbleweeds in fences have been stripped into thatch.

Thankful for the rain but, winds take it right back out. Mustard and dandelions is coming up and elm trees are budding.  A lot of different birds coming through. Don't have to dig very deep to find dry, hard soil.
Still calling it moderately dry, conditions different for late winter as it has been colder and now some precip as snow, still think soil moisture is depleted
Moving to mildly dry as past week has finally seen some moisture around here, plus has been much colder for March
Going with mildly dry and will probably shift to near normal next week if moisture continues to come, cold March, haven't started any garden or lawn preparation yet.  Late start to spring tilling.

Much melting and evaporation going on the last few days. Ground now only about 20% covered with snow where drifts had formed. Fields and pastures have standing water and running water in low spots because the ground below is still frozen and melt cannot sink in. Classic mud season.

The high winds with last Wednesday's blizzard resulted in very uneven snow distribution, varying from nearly bare ground to drifts nearly 6 feet deep. The bright sun since has melted/evaporated the snow in the thinner places and ground is now visible over about 40% of the area. It is still mud season in the heat of the day.

Mud season is here. Ground not totally thawed so standing water cannot soak into the ground everywhere. Grass has started to grow, but trees not yet greening up. Still have snow from zero to four feet deep in the forest.  Fences dragged down by the snow will have to be repaired before cattle can be brought in to graze.
0.09 in. from this weekend's storm was much needed but we are still short on moisture.
Soil is still too dry.
We received only 0.22 of an inch of precipitation from the "bomb cyclone." Snow cover was gone by Friday and our soil is still dry.
We actually have mud! The rains of 3/22/19-3/23/19 were extremely beneficial.
Continued precipitation maintaining adequate soil moisture.

After a blizzard for nearly 3 days the amount of snow acculation is in drifts around buildings. Grassland pasture has no snow cover here. As drifts melt ponds will fill. The recharge to water sands has value.

Accumulation of water from last weeks blizzard is 3 inches.
All 3 doors of my house were blocked by snow until Friday.Marooned, so could not report what had taken place.
Corrals are standing in water as snow melts,water catches 
are filling from runoff. Snow drifts in cedar & juniper trees has caused much damage to windbreak trees. High ground is drying fast from wind.
Snow depth is 54", which is 173% of average for the date. More snow is on the way. Looks like the drought is dead!
Snowfall for the date is 160", which is 132% of average. 55" of snow is on the ground today, which is 198% of average.

So far in March this station has received 66.8" of snowfall with 5.34" of water equivalent. March's average is 18" of snowfall with 1.47" of water. The 57" of snow currently on the ground is 248% of average for this date.
The snowpack at this station has been melting much slower than usual for this late in March. Current snow depth is 54" (313% of average), and total snowfall for the season is 139% of average.

We totaled 0.41" of precipitation, all in the form of 5.7" of snow, over the past week thanks to a storm from March 1-2.  The new snow cover, significantly below average temperatures (a high temperature of 10F on 3 March and a low of –11F on 4 March), and average winds during the period have allowed ground conditions to return to near normal levels.  Total February precipitation was 0.20" (about 50% of average).

We totaled 0.09" of precipitation (mostly light rain, but also 0.2" of snow) over the past week.  Lingering snow cover from last week's storm, continued below average temperatures, and light winds during the period have maintained near normal ground conditions.

A wet week, thanks to a blizzard.  A total of 0.94" of precipitation (both rain and 4.3" of new snow) fell during the past week.  Temperatures were slightly below normal, and winds were high during the blizzard but weak otherwise.  Ground conditions are about normal.  Lawn grass is just beginning to green, and garlic shoots are peeking out of the garden.

A total of 0.06" of precipitation was recorded over the past week, bringing the month-to-date total to 1.47" (120% of the climatological average).  Temperatures and wind speeds were about average.  Ground conditions remain near normal for this time of year.  Lawn grass is beginning to green up, garlic shoots are 3-4" high and onions and peas were planted.
Snowing heavily with alot of wind. Yesterday the lawn was 1/2 cleared of snow with mud visible  Today a heavy wet snow blankets everything and the blowing snow is making visibility very poor
The snow found in the yards is disappearing very quickly. The days are warm and there is alot of mud. Many migratory birds have arrived. It feels very much like spring
More moisture is helping. It is starting to melt finally.
Snow is melting fast and the ground is saturated with mud.
Snow is melting fast.  Ground is muddy.
Condition remains at Normal.  This week had warmer days and nights which melted most of the snowpack.  Yesterday's snowstorm brought 2.7" snow to report this morning.

Remains at Normal.  The past 7 days had 4.7" snow to report with .38" precipitation, with 0 degree lows for the first 2 nights.  Most snowpack is gone with the exception of the half inch of frozen rain/snow that appeared overnight.  Deer, rabbits, wild turkeys appear healthy and find lawns to graze even though there was snowpack from Jan 11 through Feb 25.  There should be abundant wild flowers in the forest behind our house this Spring.

Conditions are Mildly wet after Wednesday's snowstorm brought 14" measurable snow beginning with 0.2" rain and totaling 2.14" precipitation for this 7 days. Last Winter's Snow total was 40" yet we are at 66" already with April still to come.  Snowpack in this forested area of suburbia averages >6" snow. Temps are predicted in the 40's for the next 5 days. Deer, rabbits and wild turkeys appear healthy. Snowpack for the State of Colorado is +100% overall which is great for the water tables and reservoir supplies for this coming year.

Setting the condition at Near Normal, for this time of year after a dry 7 days. Almost all the snowpack has melted from the 14" of wet snow a week ago. Soil is thawing and muddy. However our total snowfall since late October is higher 66.0" compared to last year's dry Winter of 40.0". Robins and finches have returned to the area and survived last week's bomb cyclone force winds.  Deer, Wild turkey and rabbits appear healthy.

This 7 days were dry and windy with high day time temps at 60 to 70 degrees and warmer 40's for the lows so that no snowpack remained.  Overnight storm brought 4.5" snow measuring 0.46" precipitation.  So conditions remain Normal for this time of year in this suburban Ponderosa forest area SE of Parker.  Robins, house finches, woodpeckers have returned to the area since the second week of March.  There is optimism for better water supplies in reservoirs, etc over Colorado's statewide snowpack over 100% through this winter.
When the middle rail of our split rail fence is covered with snow, we know it's a heavy snow year.  Last year there was no snow on the ground on this date.  Bye bye drought!
Epic snowfall on our property (35 acres) this year.  Snowpack is reported to be at 135%.  Avalanche warnings for many of the surrounding areas.  Avalanche danger is at "Extreme" level (5 of 5).
The most snow on the ground I’ve seen in years. Watershed at 158%

The past week has been very warm (in the lower 40's) for this time of year. Snow melt has been extreme. The ground is saturated. Our driveway and roads (we live 10 miles from pavement) are so soft we have had to limit travel to times when the ground is frozen. The nearby lake (Forbes Park Lake aka McCarty Lake) is frozen but still extremely low. The low level is partially from the extreme drought last summer as well as this lake was used to dip water to fight the Spring Fire. There is 21 inches of snow on the ground.
Ground is snow covered everywhere after last nights snow of 3 inches. Warm days causing a lot of snow melt making it difficult to drive as the ground is very saturated.

Straddling the line between normal and a bit dry. Dried out quickly this week. Our horse corral went from mud to dust in just a few days.  But overall, vegetation is greening up about on schedule and soil moisture OK for now. With an average spring, we'll have good water supplies s mountain snowpack is in good shape

After a warm and dry start to the week we transitioned back to cold and snowy.  Some bushes and trees were about ready to burst into blossom but have been delayed -- fortunately.  Grass has really greened up as wet snow melted in moving us from mildly dry to mildly wet or at least average.  We are looking good with snowpack too.

Mountain snowpack remains a bit above average but not dramatically so.  Grass is green and some flowers and buds are bursting out now --soil moisture is OK but not great -- I'll call it "normal" but we could use more precip soon to stay on track

Green grass is quickly loosing the deep green color as soil moisture has rapidly depleted as ET rates crank up. soil is still workable but clay soils are quickly getting hard.  Got some light rain this week but not enough to keep up with average. Overall water supplies are fine.
Wet spring snow yesterday afternoon and evening. 2nd grade class visiting today did some activities inside and some outside. The temperature was 41 degrees F.

We had to abandon three vehicles while on a research project yesterday. The storm hit suddenly and the roads became so slippery that we got stuck and couldn't get out. We had to walk miles out and will have to go back and try to retrieve vehicles once it dries out.
The ground has been covered by snow most of winter. No severe cold, but colder then usual for past 6 months. Buds on fruit trees are in excellent shape.
Mulched areas still retain moisture; bare earth is dry. Lawns are showing some green as daffodils bloom.
Ground currently damp with snowfall and melting. Cold has arrested trees leafing out.
The ground is dry; lawn irrigation has started.  Perennials and trees are leafing out on schedule.

Only 0.03" of new precipitation here this week.  Yesterday 4/5/19 was the first day this spring that I would say our run-off has been about average.  We had quite a bit of water on the ground in the afternoon.  I estimate that about 35% of the ground in this area is still snow covered but it is melting quickly.  I think we are at about average or just above for moisture at this time of year.

We had 0.32" of precipitation at this station this week.  The majority of our spring runoff is probably over in this general area.  About 5% of the land around us still has snow banks from the winter that have not melted yet.  Storms this week have kept the soil around us mildly wet.
We had 0.6" of precipitation this past week.  The soil condition seems to be just about where it should be at this time of year.
We had 0.38" of precipitation at this station this week, 0.30" of which fell in the last 24 hours.  As of this report the soil is muddy in this area.
still some moisture in the ground.
Enjoying the moisture this week
some moisture still in the ground.
Still getting a little moisture, and still cool.
Some soil moisture finally.  Only have to go down a few inches to reach dry though. Kosha and Russian Thistle coming up. Elms budding.

Weather outlook isn't very promising.  No significant moisture in the forecast.  Things are turning green but, not much growth other than the mustard. Fire season seems to have already hit.  Could see smoke from the Las Animas fire all weekend.
More wind than moisture last week. Things are greening up and allergens are high. Today marks the 11th anv. of the Crowley County fire. Never want to go through that again.

Typical April weather.  Cloud up, wind blow, clouds move out.  Dirt is already moving this morning.  Cottontails have taken over the yard, eating weeds. Grass is photosynthesizing. It's going to need some moisture to keep going.
Lots of weekend clouds but no rain. Feedlot dust hanging heavy in the air and settling on everything. Just enough wind to discourage any burning.
Flipping to near normal for several reasons, March wet and cold, soil moisture looks good, farmers plowing fields and soil looks wet, late start on lawn and garden work.
Definitely mud season, supported by frequent snow events.
Things are still "Near Normal", whatever that is. It has been several days since measurable precipitation, but grass is still growing, trees are extending candles, ground is damp.
Soil moisture satisfactory, but we will need rain this week.
Continued spring precipitation has largely replenished the dry land.
Starting to get dry again, hoping for more precipitation.
Dry side of normal.
There has not been enough moisture to really give native grasses a good start.  Need a "soaker" here.
The moisture in the ground goes quite deep, which is good for planting, weeding, and general garden clean-up.
Snowpack at this station is currently 374% of average for this date. Over 6 feet of snow fell in March, bringing 5.7" of water with it. Snow is melting more slowly compared to a normal year.
Snow is now melting rapidly at this location, but still 458% of the average snowpack for this date.

Still 30" of snow on the ground at this site, which much higher than average for April 15th. Quartz Creek has not risen much at all- it is mostly ice-free but there are still snow cornices hanging over it.

A total of 0.29" of precipitation in the form of rain and 1.6" of snow was recorded over the past week.  We ended March with 1.76" of precipitation (110% of average).  Lawn grass continues to emerge, tulips are just beginning to emerge, and daffodils are blooming.

A warm and dry week.  Just 0.02" of precipitation (all rain) fell, and temperatures averaged 5 degrees above the early April average.  Patchy greening of (as yet) unirrigated lawn has slowed a bit despite the warm temperatures.  Native grasses just beginning to green.  Tulips a few inches high, with buds just emerging on some trees and shrubs.

Major and minor spring snow storms delivered a total of 1.21" of precipitation this week, mostly in the form of snow (10.9").  Temperatures went from well above average (high of 78F on 8 Apr to well below average (high of 42F on 11 Apr).  Winds were generally light; this, combined with snow cover on 4 days, allowed ground conditions to become mildly wet.  Lawn grass is mostly green, though short; tulips are close to budding; ash and peach trees have larger buds.

Another 0.24" over the past week.  Ground conditions are about normal for this time of year given the precipitation but also countered by above normal temperatures (a high of 79F on 20 April) and moderate winds (gusting to 34 mph on 18 April) that increased surface evaporation.  Plum tree has white flowers, ash has larger bugs, peach is budding, and lawn grass will need to be cut soon.

Just 0.01" of precipitation this week (rain).  Temperatures were above normal and winds were moderate to strong (gusting to 41 mph) leading to above normal surface evaporation.  But there is enough residual surface moisture that ground conditions remain about normal.  The first grass mowing occurred on 28 April.
Drought is almost over.
My yard is drying out and road is very dusty.
Winter had good moisture but could use more. Flowers are coming up and heard my first hummingbird of the season today.

Near Normal for this time of year.  A dry 7 days past, with low's in the 40's highs in the 60's and a few Trace amounts of precipitation.  House finches are earnestly nesting.  Deer in this suburban forest appear normal and seem to have come through the winter fine.

Near Normal for this time of year here.  3 days of Trace precipitation, an 8" snowfall midweek, and 1" snow in a quick shower yesterday.  Previous week had no moisture.  The ground is thawing and muddy. Great moisture for trees  and lawns are quickly turning green.  Birds are nesting everywhere.  No hummingbirds in the area yet.

Remains Near Normal. Lawns are green now,aspens and fruit trees are budding, with 0.06" precipitation this 7 days. Word has it the hummingbirds have appeared, with the flowering of wildflowers, dandelions, early perennials.
Snow is melting rapidly. There is approximately 50% coverage. Snow has melted away from dirt roads enough they are generally passable.
The recent showers over the past couple of weeks has helped green things up.  4" of snow overnight will get the ground in good condition for planting our annual flower seeds later this week.
Pastures very wet and dryland areas lush.  Wildflowers are late due to cold and snow.
Good to know that the fire danger will be reduced this spring and early summer

Ground is saturated due to above normal precip.
Snow and rain in the CO mountains has Colorado River level rising quickly and very muddy.
Run-off is good for white water rafting. Not good for fishing.
Garden plants, shrubs and trees looking healthy.

We are in our normal wet season and are near normal in terms of precipitation and impacts -- even though we had a wet snow early this past week, that's not unusual for  this time, either. Grass is green, flowers are blooming at about their normal spring bloom dates.  Water supplies are good.  All is well -- so far.

With the help of another cool damp week with a little bit more snow on Thursday. I would now say we’re on the wet side of average but only a little.The grass is green and lush water supplies look good for the year coming up

Finally some warm weather this week the company by a few light showers. Now it’s chilly and damp again. Overall, near normal for this time of year in terms of soil moisture, green vegetation, and surface water supplies. Still haven’t planted the garden due to cool soils.  Lilacs now in full bloom a bit later than usual.Rivers were rising after three days of hot weather this week but now they’re retreating a bit again. Mountain snow in the forecast for the next two days

After a cool, wet week with a late-spring snow, I'd now say we're on the wet side.  Vegetation is lush. Lilacs are still in full bloom (later than average) and ag activities are lagging behind. Bird migrations still in progress with many beauties still passing through this past week.  High mountains still plastered in snow, so runoff will be large when it get's rolling again
Due to the severe drought last year and cold wet winter, flies, grasshoppers, wild bees are no where in sight. honeybees are also few. Pollination is minimum at best.

Walking into the woods has several areas of damp ground. Springs continue to seep creating spots for wildlife watering.  No sign of bears coming near homes.  Deer are eating leaves from budding oak brush & wild grasses. Early Perennials haven't bloomed yet. A few robins have returned & hummingbirds.

Wet snow made the roads muddy again and several sections in the woods that are shaded. Perennials still haven't bloomed although have buds on them. A bear was seen above our acreage.  It ate the goats food and the next night when we had 4" of snow, it left paw prints on their deck where it ate the grease from their grill.  No one else has reported any sightings. The scat I saw had grasses in it, don't think they have any ripe berries up higher.  None here for them.
Grass green and growing.  This 8 inches of snow melted into my lawn and soaked the fertilizer I had spread into the lawn.
It's been a wet, cold week with fog, snow and rain,  Surroundings look like an east coast spring -- very unusual after living here over 25 years.
Soil is dry.  We've had a few sprinkles,  but with high (80's) temperatures we are dry.
6 days of cooler temperatures and overcast skies.  The effects of late May snow still being observed. Fruit trees being monitored.

The past two months have provided much needed precipitation. As the temperatures start warming up it is becoming clear that some of my young trees and shrubs did not survive the early months of our dry winter. I will give them more time to show signs of life, but I am not hopeful.

The first 3 days of this week we got 1.39" of precipitation, which is more than we sometimes get in a month.  It has dried out a little bit toward the end of the week.  Precipitation total for the month of April was 102% of the 10 year average at this station, but the snowfall for April of this year was only 28% of the 10 year average. The grass is greening up nicely, but our meadow is still showing signs of last year's drought, mostly that the grass isn't growing very fast and there are still some bare spots.

The first part of this week was dry but later in the week we got 0.24" of precipitation, so as of this morning things are still a little bit muddy.  Meadow grass is not growing very fast at this point but it is sure green.

There was some drying out of soil this week due to windy, dry conditions.  We did have 0.11" of precipitation overnight, so I think we are probably near normal for this time of year.  Grass is looking very green but still isn't growing very fast in this area.  I think drought damaged areas of the pasture will be slow recovering.
We've had over an inch of precipitation in the past week which doesn't happen all that often in this area.
It feels like it has been a cold and wet spring. Plants and migrating birds are about a week later than previous years. Almost an inch of rain last week.
Ground conditions a little more moisture than normal, but grass showing some stress.
With almost a half inch of rain this week, the soil will be nice for planting and moving landscape plants this week.
moisture reflects spring conditions - cool weather and a shower now and then.
Great moisture this week. Cloudy this morning. Hoping more is on its way.
mostly seems like a "normal" spring, still snow at highter elevations, nice warm days
Total of .17" last week.  Plenty of wind. Still kick up dust.

Not willing to move up to mildly dry.  Total of .30" last week won't last long with the winds we keep getting.  Cattle still kick up the dust.  Big pair of coyotes through the yard this morning. Plenty of cottontails for them. Things are really greening up.  Wish the TV meteorologists would stop complaining about the "bad weather". Those of us that depend on moisture would gladly take all that the front range has been getting.

A lot of wind but no moisture last week. Takes a loader to drive a t-post,with several being bent. Things are green but there isn't much there yet. Livestock hunting for feed and getting out of pastures to do so.
Wind almost every day.  Was good to get the 1" rain but, is still difficult to make step-in posts work. The Kosha and Russian Thistle are really starting to take off. Nice to see green!
Near normal conditions are great, and a much welcomed change from 2018 at this time of the year.  All of the plants on and around my property appear to be healthy and green.

Conditions have been better this winter with several late snow and rain events that have helped increase the soil moisture, stress levels on vegetation and the fire danger.  Hopefully the wet snow events will help the wildflowers blooming that we usually get later this month.  We already have our early bloomers, the Pasque Flowers or Meadow Anenomes that have emerged in good numbers this year, with many already blooming by the beginning of May.
Here's a first tilting to moderately wet! 7.5" of snow, rain and cool temps have changed the scenery. Should be a green spring!
Staying with mildly wet on this report, more moisture, cooler temps keeping conditions good, no drought on the near future, pasture looks great!
Off and on rains, nice temps, typical spring, runoff on the Poudre slow to start, staying with mildly wet, dry-land pasture looks great.
Staying with mildly wet as it rain while I submit this report.  Dryland pasture looks great, all grasses doing very well, soil moisture in top foot looks really good.

very welcome change from last years drought.  no irrigation required yet this spring and trees shrubs and grasses as well as flowering plants are thriving. I hope it continues but am bracing for the return of dry weather that usually occurs this time of year.
Garden soil is nicely damp, but not muddy.  Pasture is greening up well.
Gloriously green and lush.  More like the upper midwest where I grew up than the normal semi-arid great plains.  Soil moisture is good, approaching too wet to cultivate, but still ok.
Although we haven't had much precipitation for several days, moisture in the ground is still pretty good. Grass is growing well, springs are running, fire danger is not high.

The last 15.7" snow has melted already leaving soft fields, some muddy conditions and enthusiastically growing grass. This will, of course, result in higher wildfire danger later in the summer as the plants dry, but for now it is very green.
Alfalfa and grass coming along but a bit short, perhaps due more to low temperatures than low precipitation.

Major media have been saying the drought is over. We believe this statement is premature. Since November 1, 2018, we have had only 3.64 inches of precipitation. When it warms up we will need more rain in a hurry.
In spite of nickel size hail, yesterday's thunderstorm was very beneficial.
This week's beneficial rains are very good for the land.
Very dry Fall & Winter months. Finally March & April brought us back to about average conditions.
Average conditions. It's usually a little wet in May.

Our soil was showing signs of moisture content , dark areas of undisturbed soil visible to the eye plus when burying dead birds a foot down soil was moist dark , before the blizzard in March . It has stayed that way since then plus some . All the trees look great except from hail damage from last year and already once this year , the pines and junipers are nice and green . The deciduous are leafing out and blossoms are trying except for hail , frost , ice and snow so they are on hold .

We are soaked after the last storm . Our dog was digging a whole about 10" down and it was almost like mush . In trial the storm damage yesterday I accidently knocked down a nest I could not see and it had 3 dead baby birds in it from the storm . Our fields are the greenest I seen in 4 years . All the pine trees are looking great , the deciduous were just starting to leaf out so not much storm damage . Will have to see what happens with new growth . The snow splayed all our lilacs that were in bloom but all but one very large old one  , 9' to 10' , have stood back up . Most all received some damage but the blooms look alright for now . Not as many blooms as previous years because off all the hail last year and late and early freezing and hail this year .

This Spring has been much colder and wetter than previous years. It is a wonderful change from the rather terrifying fire danger present during last year. However, it is annoying to have snow and cold weather on May 10, when I would rather go golfing in warm weather.
All gardening and landscaping has been suspended, since the ground is quite saturated.
Didn't have to worry about watering trees, shrubs, and lawn while on vacation.  Things are greening up nicely, and the air is clean.
Heavy rain and snow (10") fell over the past 5 days. Mud Mud Mud! The snow is still deep in the trees and north facing slopes at this elevation.
13.3" of snow and 1.37" of precipitation have fallen in the first 10 days of May. Ground is saturated and the long mud season continues.
Most of the snow has melted at this elevation, except on shady & north-facing slopes. Creeks and spring flows are up slightly.

Snowfall continues at this station, but it melts fast. Ground is saturated and spring flows are running high. Major run-off from high elevation snow has not begun yet, so creeks are still running near normal.

May is closing as the snowiest May in my records, going back to 2012. We've received 23.7" of snow in May thus far along with 2.54" of precip. The snowpack at higher elevations has not changed much, so there is a potential for flooding when the weather warms up and that snow really starts to melt.

A wet, cold start to the week becoming sunny, warm, and dry by the end.  We totaled 0.69" of liquid precipitation (4.3" of new snow) from a late April storm, then temperatures warmed into the 70s.  Given the snowfall and seasonally light to moderate winds, ground conditions ticked up to mildly wet.  April ended with 1.98" of precipitation (roughly equal to the 1981-2010 average), which came partly in the form of 15.1" of snow (240% of average).  Peach tree has stopped flowering and now small green leaves are emerging.  Plum trees are covered in small white flowers, and leaves on pear are just beginning to emerge.

We received 0.52" of precipitation (0.7" of snow) this week.  This will likely be the final snow of the season.  Temperatures began the week well below average (40s F) but warmed into the 70s F by week's end.  The precipitation and cool temperatures, along with light winds, have kept ground conditions slightly wet for this time of year.  We are very close to average precipitation for the past week, the month of May, and year-to-date.

We received 0.39" of precipitation (all rain) over the past week, which is actually below the average weekly precipitation for mid-May (0.53").  Temperatures reached into the mid-80s F (85F on 15 May) and then dropped back to below-normal levels (50s F) by week's end.  Winds were about average.  All fruit trees have leafed out (or are in the process of), ash and locust are in the process of leafing, lilacs are in full bloom.

A total of 0.22" of precipitation (0.1" of snow) fell over the past week.  Temperatures have been remarkably cool:  the average temperature of 40.2F (avg high 46.4, avg low 33.9F) observed at this station during the period 19-24 May 2019 was the coldest such mid-May period on record in the CSU main campus weather station weather archives (records date back to the 1880s).  The cool temperatures, combined with light winds and continued precipitation, have left ground conditions mildly wet for this time of year.

since I live on a dirt road that goes up a hill, the mud is really deep.  I can get in and out to my house with 4-wheel drive, but it is a project.  Actually it is not a problem, I have lived here for years, and know what is coming.  I end up cleaning the house, reading, napping etc when the mud gets like this.  Why tear up a car just to get to the post office.  The mail will still be there when it drys out.
My dirt road is a mud bog with deep ruts. Flowers are loving the rain.
Dry on top but damp under the roots. Grass hay is green and higher than normal. Corn is sprouting up.
The fields are green and lush. The ground is damp under the plants
Not having to do hand watering yet.
It feels like it has been a cold and wet spring but it is still in the normal range.  Plants and migrating birds are about a week later than previous years.
Continued wet weather has tremendously reduced fire danger and improved health of my forest.

Condition remains Normal.  The rain gauge for the past 2 weeks has collected 1.25" precipitation and we had rain, sleet and snow.  After several dry days now the lawns are green and growing, perennial flowers are blooming and tulips and daffodils are finished.  All trees are leafing out.  Hummingbirds have been in the area for several weeks and more are showing up.  Overnight low this morning was 42 so still a little cool.  Highs this week will be in the 80's.  Definitely changeaable weather. Bicycle riders are appearing on streets and trails after a cold winter.

Even though there was only a Trace of precipitation the past 7 days the condition remains at normal for this time of year.  Rain has begun this morning and is predicted to continue for a couple of days with possibility of freezing temps and snow.  It is rare to wake up to rain here!

Condition remains Normal for this time of year in the high ground East of the front range with typical springtime changes in the weather pattern. 7 days ago we reported 1.5" precipitation with 8" snow and several days later the skies were blue, no snow remaining, with high temps in the mid 70's. Typical for this time of year. The week ended with quick moving thunderstorm bands through the area yesterday with hail and turbulent winds. Here we got only 0.07" with minimal hail. Today dawns blue skies and highs expected in 70's.  Homeowners are planting tomato plants with an eye out for hail so they can cover plants quickly.  Perennials are blooming this week with warmer weather.  The ground has a nice amount of moisture. No water restrictions predicted for this summer due to the nice snowpack in the mountains this winter.

We have an irrigation ditch running through our property.  They opened the water up full blast yesterday due to worries that Spring Park Reservoir might overtop.  The reservoir was nearly empty last year - especially after the fire fighting helicopters were using it as a water source.  That ditch ran for very few days last year.  Our watershed is currently reported at 151% of normal (source:  Roaring Fork Conservancy).

All the snow cover has melted, but the ground is still saturated.  Our irrigation ditch is running at full blast due to concerns that the reservoir may overtop with spring melt.  The local rivers are running very high for this time of year.  Watershed is reported to be over average levels.

Above average moisture around here.  Our irrigation ditch is still running at maximum capacity. Low areas are too muddy to run a tractor without tearing up the land.  The pastures are green and the mountains are white.  We have spectacular spring conditions!

It's been a very wet winter and spring here. Our irrigation ditch is still running at maximum capacity - even overtopping in places (due to fears that the reservoir might overtop). Low areas are too muddy to run a tractor without tearing up the land. The pastures are green and the mountains are white.  Snowpack and watershed reports well above average levels (source: Roaring Fork Conservancy).
Thick, green pasture, irrigation ditch still running at maximum capacity.  RFV Conservancy reports the watershed to be at 391% of average (compared to 70% last year).
Grass is starting to turn green. Mud is gone for now.
Two feet of heavy wet snow fell earlier this week. Roads are very muddy. Snow is melting quickly.
Pounded wooden posts into ground with sledge hammer!
Pulled cows off pasture (too wet)
Grass is stressed early growth is slow

We've had nearly an inch of precipitation this past week--three quarters of which was heavy, wet snow that melted quickly. Tulips are blooming and irises are just starting to. Buds are appearing on lilacs and most trees in the area. March and April each provided 2" of rain which broke a three month dry spell where monthly precipitation never exceeded 0.19".

We've had a little over a third of an inch of rain/snow the past week. No frost. The grass, tulips and iris plants thriving. Trees are budding. A three day period of clouds has turned to sunny conditions today.

We have had very little rain or snow moisture in March.  A total for .57 inches at my house.  March was slightly warmer than normal 1.7 degrees.  I took several core samples, 2 inches deep and all of the crumbled in my hands.  Hope we get more rain in May.  So far 0.0 inches.

Walking in the forest this year there is no crunching, crispy sound like last year. The pine duff is moist. Different wildflowers are popping up with near normal rain/snowfall. Bend Creek, which was dry last year is running full this year. The roads in this rural area have been pretty muddy with the consistent precipitation. Grass, oak and other plants are returning in some of the burned areas, but not where the Spring Creek fire was super hot. A relief to have normal precipitation.

Patches of snow remain in the forest at 4-10" in depth. Forest roads are running like creeks with the recent snowmelt. Water is pooling in flat areas. 2018-2019 season snowfall is at 210.25". If 2018-2019 season rainfall is converted to snowfall equivalent, our 6.22" of rain = about 62" of snow this season. A total of 272" of snow equivalent! Be prepared to get muddy hiking or walking!
Flowers that have not appeared in 2 years are popping up. Plenty of turkeys and deer.

The soils here at 8500 feet on Raspberry mountain, where not burned, not disturbed and in areas free of pine duff, have remained wet enough that mosses are beginning to form a green velvety covering. I have not seen this at all the last 2 springs.

The ground seems mildly dry and the weather has been cooler. Most of the neighbors are able to tend the surrounding yards and the dandelions are in full assault. The flowering crab trees are in full bloom. On our bike rides, my son reports that the bodies of water near our home seem to have lower water levels that he recalls seeing in previous years. Many wildflowers are blooming. The white pelicans have arrived and the birds are in full nesting with no baby birds seen yet.

Received rain in the past week which was very helpful to green up the lawns and other plants. Evenings and nights are very cool with frost on the grass on a couple of mornings. We are able to plant some plants outside to begin a garden.
Many days of rain have made it difficult to mow the lawn as it remains very wet. The plants around the house are very green. This is a nice change from one year ago.

Recent late snow in the mountains and rain, with overnight lows near or a little above freezing, are ideal for gardening. Cool season transplants are thriving under row covers, and tender annuals growing strong in the greenhouse (which is staying above 45F overnight).
No need to water perennials.
There is still snow at high elevations, which bodes well for ground moisture through the spring and hopefully into summer at least.  Lower wildfire risk with spring winds when the soil is wet.
Was hoping to plant potatoes today but soil may be too wet and soil temperature too cool.  Other cool season crops growing well under cover with recent moisture.
late season snow 5/9
No impacts, just watering the lawn less frequently.

Although we received rain this week we have had less than 1/2 inch this month. I do not think this is a large area that is dry because surrounding areas seem to have gotten more moisture this spring and winter. Here there are cracks in the lawn and the garden is dry to the depth it was plowed. Lawns that havent had supplemental water are turning brown.
Much more moisture this spring compared to last.  Still need heavy rain to fill dry ponds which have been empty for the last 3 years.

Four days this past week were very wet and even included snow.  At my station we received a total of 1.32" of precipitation (2" of snow one day).  Our grass is very green and lush and has to be mowed more often than normal.  The hiking trails in town have been very muddy during and immediately after the rain/snow, inhibiting that form of outdoor recreation.  But the wet weather is usually followed by a quick warm up and dry out so the trails become passable again within a few days.  There have been no fire bans and no nearby wildfires lately.  There are no watering restrictions.  We turned on the heat during the 4 days of wet weather since it also got pretty cold for this time of year.

It was a dry week until yesterday afternoon with warm temperatures.  Yesterday afternoon we got a strong thunderstorm with some hail.  The trails were not muddy and hiking was good.  Grass is very green and lush from previous weeks of rain.  No wildfires nearby.  No restrictions.  Turned on the heat for the first time last night in a while as we head into another cooler, wet period.

It was another very wet, cool week with 1.55" total precipitation including 3.5" of snow at my station.  Temperatures were generally in the 40s, well below normal for this time of year.  Our heat was on most of the week.  Grass is very green and long.  I didn't try to hike due to the weather.  No wildfires, fire or watering restrictions. Starting yesterday things dried out and temperatures are back to normal.
More moisture in soil than usual, more flowers blooming this spring than in recent years.

Moderately wet in that this level of soil moisture is higher than normal for May in this location over that past 20 years on our farm. Moisture present at least down one foot in garden, unirrigated fields have more veg growth than normal, irrigation ditch still running strong with about 240% of average snow water equivalent at 10200 foot SNOTEL gauge at headwaters of our La Plata River. Cool temps slowing down our planting, but with the moisture, we feel fortunate nevertheless. Fortunate also that the cooler temps are keeping the snowmelt rate moderate -- for now at least!

Snowmelt from the mountains will accelerate this week causing high river flows.   More rain here this week was not excessive but has kept everything very green.  Garden still not planted but it's time now. Great to have no wildfire concern but that may change with all the grass growth this spring.

Normal for this time of year. ET rates are cranking up and precipitation is tapering off although we had a few showers again this week.  Rivers are high now that the snow melt is going full speed ahead. No wildfires yet —very nice

after a week of frequent storms, higher humidity, cool temperatures and abundant cloud cover at the time of year when summer heat is usualy setting in, we are now definitely on the wet side. Hay has been cut -- some got it in dry, others got caught with hay down. Fire danger wonderfully low, and surface water supplies generous 00 snow in mountains means more snow melt yet to come. Vegetation lush and green even without irrigation.  But N CO recreation and tourism would appreciate more sun and warmer temperatures -- that's coming soon.
Seemingly frequent rains but still only tracking near average  Cool weather is stretching our water resources by reducing demands

Quick showers forest floor is still damp, oak brush is leaving out, no berries yet.  Scat of bear showed eating grasses. My outdoor wildlife camera showed a light colored bear on the lower deck last month.  Still have the muddy paw prints on our glass door left last August. Still waiting for my flowers to bloom.

Little rains have kept the soil moist & creeks provide water for wildlife to keep them away from homes. A few bears have ventured to a home nearby where food for a goat lured them. The deer are shedding their winter coats & my poppies are blooming.  The Iris's are slow to open, but things in the woods are green with wildflowers coming up.

Oak brush is abundant, no nuts or berries visible in the forest where we walk. The ground is getting dry. Our neighbor had her 3rd bear encounter.  It chased her goat up onto her deck. When she woke to the noise, she found the goat at her door and a 2 year old cub close behind. The goat has horns, she thinks it could defend itself, but I told her bears do eat new fawns as no other food is available. If a bear cripples her goat, it cant defend itself. This goat is a left over project from her girls in 4H, she needs to consider taking the goat elsewhere, this brings problems not only to her door, but the other 4 of us nearby. They've lived here longer than any of us, but needs to consider others now.
Yesterdays rain didn't add much to the soil moisture. Saw my first Robin, about a month behind.  Not many fawns being seen either. So far no bears reported.
Most trees still in spring green with cool to mild temperatures. Tulips just finishing and iris starting.  This is a late spring.
We've had lots of potential rain, but very little fell.  Established perennials need extra water.
Clouds and thunder almost everyday, but no rain. Some trees: oaks, locust are still in spring green and catalpas haven't budded yet.

With rain yesterday and continuing today we may get closer to normal.  Most trees are now summer green. Catalpas are just blooming as the roses open up.  Prior to Friday, hand watering was necessary for perennials.
The temperatures have see sawed in the last 7 days.  Yesterday the temperatures were above normal and supplemental watering was necessary.  Evening rain has been very brief and spotty.

I will keep us at moderately wet for another week.  We had 0.75" of precipitation for the week and a total of 2.55" for the month of May which is really pretty wet for this area. Vegetation is looking nice and green.
The weather has dried out somewhat here this week so I will drop us down a category from where we were last week.

The weather has been drier so far this month, which is typical of June in this area.  I was prepared to put us in the "normal" category, but yesterday afternoon we had 0.17" of rain/hail, so I will keep us in the mildly wet category. Vegetation is still very green and is growing well. Neighboring hay fields are looking good so far.
We've had 1.27" of precipitation this week in the form of rain, hail and snow. That's unusual in this area for June and it's more than we see in an entire month sometimes.

This week has been dry but there is still a lot of dew on the grass in the mornings and we are still above average soil/water conditions for this time of year. Grass/hay crop is not the best I've seen in this area but compared to last year it is very much improved, and may be a very good year depending on the weather in the next few weeks.
We haven’t needed to run the sprinkler system for the lawn yet this year.
A bit more moisture this week and soil still moist.
With over an inch of rain this week, we're probably moderately wet. the last one came down hard and fast but it's nice to have the soil moisture.
After last night's downpour, ground is very wet.  Have only irrigated the lawn one time, but watered plants last week.
The ground is quite saturated and taking longer to soak in.Plants are loving it.
Very hot conditions have erased the moisture from the past weeks.
Lots of green, for now. Rains are hanging all around but not hitting much here. Plants are getting that "dull" look. They need a good bath!

Muddy in spots but, raise the dust right beside it. Pastures are slow to green up, they still have a brown look to them. Our puddle of a pond has already evaporated. Rains are very scattered and spotty.
We should get about half an inch in June but received only 0.14" at this location. Irrigation from snow melt is all that is keeping us going.
All thing green and nice looking right now, streams are starting to run and reservoirs are filling.
More rain during this past week and cold temps, no drought here, river running high, pasture all green
3.7 inches over the last month very beneficial to the land.
Calendar year to date we have had 1.99 inches more this year than last year.
Throughout the spring we have received enough precipitation that we have not had to irrigate our hay.
Just about the right amount of rain.
Hot and dry is our near normal.

We have received only 0.64" over our 12 year average rainfall for the year to this date. Our grass, trees and soil condition is in  excellent condition. This has to be a result of showers coming in perfect timing. Also we had below average temperatures in Feb. March and May.

After the last heavy wet snow, broke a lot of branches on my pines, we had a low humidity dry windy day a few days later. The fields had been nice and green and soil dark but the fields dulled and the ground dried out near the surface in one day . Since then the fields have greened back some but the soil only has a few minor dark areas showing and most is dry 2" to 3" down, mostly in full sun. Since that snow 2 weeks ago Monday night we have only had traces to .01" to .02" of precipitation, at least no dry windy days . We could use more rain soon . The field grasses are close to needing a mowing. The trees and shrubs are looking good except for a lot of die back from lots of last years hail and some this year plus last years late freezes and this years late freezes, 3, after trees and shrubs had started to leaf out. I have 100 ponderosa pines I have trimmed out the storm damage but still have to raise the skirts some more for fire danger and I still have to check over 200 cedars, Colorado blue juniper, for storm damage and trim the die back out of the deciduous trees and shrubs , some serious die back in top of ashes that were growing beautiful last year. I even watered, soaked soil, them 2 to 3 times a year the last 2 years because of the drought. Too many hail welts and early freezing. I don't now if I will get my garden in, running out of time .

I got busy and forgot last weeks but and would have posted near normal but on the drier side and now near normal on the wet side . All looks good, nice and green with good soil moisture. Field grasses are green and long and seeding, will start mowing in next few days. Pines were pollinating heavily last week and are winding down now with new growth starting to open up. The spring flower blossom is almost ended . It had been ten days since any appreciable rain had fallen until yesterday.

Trying to get field grass cut, it's going crazy 1' to 1.5' tall. It's cut around house, 2 acres. All trees and shrubs are growing profusely. All nice and green. Precipitation since beginning of the year. 1/2019-.53", 2/2019-.36", 3/2019-2.05", 4/2019-.97", 5/2019-2.60", 6/2019-1.62" so far, total for the year to date is 8.13". Wild life is flourishing this year, not much hail so far .

A total of 0.48" of rain fell over the past week.  The weather began the week cool and damp but then became warm and generally drier toward the end of the period with isolated thunderstorms.  Climatological average precipitation for this period is 0.58".  May ended with 2.31" of precipitation (3.2" of snow), which is 105% of the 1981-2010 average at the CSU main campus weather station (average May snow is 0.7").  Have only irrigated lawn once this year, but that looks to change this week.  Ground conditions seem to be about normal for this time of year.

We received 0.29" of rain the past week.  Temperatures were above average with highs in the 80s F with a short cool-down late week.  Winds were gusty at times, elevating surface evaporation.  Finally had to turn on the lawn irrigation system today -- usually this is done in mid-May.  Ground conditions are about normal for this time of year.

Another week of light precipitation (0.07"), near-normal temperatures, and light winds have maintained near-normal ground conditions, but tending slightly toward the dry side.  We could use a thunderstorm soaker.

Precipitation this week totaled a healthy 1.35" (expected weekly precipitation for this part of June is 0.44").  Temperatures have been well below average -- highs in the 60s F on 4 of the 7 days -- and winds have been generally light.  Ground conditions have ticked up to mildly wet.

May was cooler and wetter than average. Almost daily afternoon thunderstorms in June. Even with misses or small amounts, brings coolness to air. Haven't had to water grass. Winter wheat fields west of the house are full and lush. Even open fields are green and weeds are growing tall.
Ground is damp around base of grass roots. The growth is very green.
Ground damp enough to keep every thing green
Wet winter took us out of a drought.  Grass is very green and good moisture in the soil.  Planted flowers and only top inch is dry.
Drying out quickly with warmer temps and no rains.
Getting dry but is normal for June. Still moist under the first few inches.

Normal conditions for the end of May, low temps still in mid 40's with a bit of rain each day totaling 0.17" for the week.  More hummingbirds are at the feeders. After this Winter's good amounts of snow, the iris plants have lots of flower stalks that seem exceptionally tall this year.  And the growth on ponderosa pine trees seem unusually long this year.

Normal conditions remain this week with 3 days of a bit of measured precipitation totaling 0.18". For the first Summer in several years there is NO mention of water restrictions.  Pine trees have released that infamous "yellow dust" which covers driveways, cars and plants.  Iris and lilacs are in bloom and lawns need cutting every week now.

Remains at Normal for this time of year, and for the first time in several years we are not concerned about water restrictions this Summer.  This week had 4 days of measureable, if minimal, moisture.  But things can change quickly.  Tomato plants are growing now that lows are around 50 each night.  Large yellow butterflies are just beginning to appear here at our station elevation 6200 feet.

Moving the condition to mildly wet after this week's total precipitation of 1.04".  Only one day with no rain to report in the past 7. Daytime highs were in the 70's all week as well. Last night's heavy rain of 0.8" combined with today's 80% chance rain will keep the hills staying green for a while.

Returning to Normal conditions for this time of year after the previous week was Mildly Wet.  The temps finally got to 90's for several days which dried out the long meadow grass behind our lawn.  Last night's thunderstorm dropped 0.10" with lots of wind.  After not running the sprinkler system for several weeks of Mildly Wet conditions, we did turn it on yesterday before the storm and will watch for dryness.  Tomato plants are finally growing with the warm days and nights but didn't grow most of June.  Flowers setting on.

The irrigation ditch on our property is still running at full blast and everything is very green this spring (including Basalt Mountain which had a 13,000 acre fire last year).  However, we haven’t had a decent rain (over 1/4”) in over 20 days.  There is lots of virga rain and wind, but nothing is hitting the ground.

With less than 1/10” of precipitation since June 1 (17 days), the ground is really starting to dry out.  Our irrigation is still running at top capacity.  Rivers are running very high due to worries of snow melt to come with warmer temperatures.
It was dry from 6/1 - 6/17, but we’ve had some good rain in the last week.  The fields are really green, our irrigation ditch continues to run at the top and the local rivers are dangerously high.
Very green; wild strawberries and wood violets blooming
No flooding, but lots of puddles and extra springs and waterfalls.
As the weather warms up the lawn and flowers need water. It seems normal for this time of year.
Having received rain frequently the ground seems mildly wet.

It was another week of alternating warm/dry with a period if wet/cool weather,  A total of .37 inches of precipitation fell including a brief hailstorm on 5/27.  The hiking trails I traveled yesterday in my town were about 95% dry with some areas of mud easily passed.  I saw many people out hiking,  No fire or watering restrictions,  Grass is growing high and needing more frequent mowing than usual.  Heat was on during the 3-day cool, rainy weather,

I was out of town last week and suspect it was quite dry as the rain gauge was empty when I returned (though some might have evaporated).
